sub_topic: Finding the period and amplitude of trigonometric functions
message_1: A student is given the trigonometric function f(x) = 3sin(2x + π/4). Find the period and amplitude of this function.
message_2:
The given function is f(x) = 3sin(2x + π/4).

The amplitude of a trigonometric function is the absolute value of the coefficient of the sine or cosine term. In this case, the amplitude is |3| = 3.

The period of a trigonometric function is the length of one complete cycle of the function. For a sine or cosine function, the period is found by dividing the standard period (2π for sine and cosine) by the absolute value of the coefficient of the x term inside the sine or cosine. In this case, the coefficient of the x term is 2. So, the period is (2π)/|2| = 2π/2 = π.

Thus, the amplitude of the function is 3 and the period is π.
